title: Juncker criticizes von der Leyen over ‘European way of life’ commissioner
text:
Outgoing President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker (left) welcomes his successor, Ursula von der Leyen, on July 23, 2019, 2019 in Brussels | John Thys/AFP via Getty Images Juncker criticizes von der Leyen over ‘European way of life’ commissioner The outgoing Commission president said he did not like the implication that accepting migrants is against European values.

Jean-Claude Juncker criticized the decision of his successor to create a commissioner for "Protecting the European Way of Life" because it suggested that welcoming migrants is against the Continent's values.

Ursula von der Leyen's top team, announced on Tuesday, included responsibility for migration in the remit of Greece's new commissioner, Margaritis Schinas, under the newly created portfolio. But the decision triggered an immediate backlash from different political parties, who objected to the use of "dog-whistle" phrase used by the far-right, calling it an "insult" and "not acceptable."

In a highly unusual intervention before von der Leyen has formally taken over at the Berlaymont, Juncker told Euronews he objected to the move and predicted it would be reversed.

"I don't like the idea that the European way of life is opposed to migration. Accepting those that come from far away is part of the European way of life," said the outgoing Commission president. The "European Way of Life" meant merging main talents and energies, and respecting others irrespectively of their color and origin, Juncker said.

He added that the job title didn't correspond with the values of Schinas, who had been his chief spokesperson during the past five years.

Senior Renew Europe MEP Pascal Canfin said Wednesday his group would demand von der Leyen change the portfolio title.

Commission spokesperson Mina Andreeva said Thursday she had “no name change or any changes to announce,” adding that “at the moment, there’s clearly no quick decision.”
description: The outgoing Commission president said he did not like the implication that accepting migrants is against European values.
